 VIETNAM WATER SUPPLY PROJECT I. BACKGROUND A. Population and Development 1.1 Vietnam is the second most populous country in Southeast Asia with a 1995 population of 74 million projected to reach 80 million by 2000. About 15 million (20%) of the population is urban. Four major cities Ho Chi Minh City, Hanoi, Danang and Haiphong account for 37% of the urban population with the remainder living in about 500 locations. About 80% of the urban population is concentrated in 77 cities with population over 15,000. 1.2 Literacy (over 90t for adult males and females) and life expectancy (68 years) are above the less developed country (LDC) averages while access to safe water supply (50% urban, 25% rural) is below the LDC average. Lack of safe water and adequate sanitation facilities are the major causes of Vietnam's higher incidence of water-borne and hygiene-related diseases such as gastroenteritis, dysentery, typhoid, cholera and hepatitis which also contribute to childhood morbidity and mortality. The ten leading causes of morbidity and mortality are practically all due to communicable diseases, most of them preventable. 1.3 Economic growth has accelerated with the introduction of reforms in 1986. Since then it has averaged around 7-8 percent per annum leading to increased urbanization (estimated to grow by 70% in next ten years) and rising urban incomes. Foreign investment has been attracted to Vietnam but limited by infrastructure constraints in urban areas. Infrastructure in most cities and towns, laid at the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th centuries, has not been adequately maintained or upgraded because of resource constraints. 1.4 The Government has responded to the above by adopting in 1991 the Socio- Economic Stabilization and Development Strategy to the Year 2000. The aspects of the strategy relevant to the proposed project are to: (i) focus limited resources available to develop infrastructure to promote investment in services and industries in three priority areas: (a) Hanoi-Haiphong- Quang Ninh; (b) Ho Chi Minh City-Bien Hoa-Vung Tau; and (c) the Danang area; (ii) streamline the number of line ministries, focus policy-making within the central government and decentralize implementation to local governments; and (iii) improve the management mechanism of state enterprises, experiment and gradually expand the transformation of state enterprises into private companies. B. Water Supply and Sanitation 1.5 Water supply and sanitation infrastructure has been affected by extreme resource constraints in the past, by lack of access to quality materials due to isolation of the Vietnamese economy, by the socio-political necessity for state enterprises to spread resources thinly in providing basic services free or for minimum fee to as many as possible, and by the acceptance of minimal service standards by consumers during times of national adversity. Given the conditions, the performance of the Water Supply Companies (WSCs) has been quite remarkable.
 2 1.6 Piped water is available to about 50% of the urban population with access ranging between 60%-80% in large cities and under 30% in other towns. However, material quality, cumulative deferred maintenance over decades, and inadequate expansion have taken their toll. Pumping and treatment facilities are overloaded and inefficient with ageing and non-compatible equipment leading to unit power consumption double international averages while distribution systems leak excessively. As a result, service is intermittent with low pressure, per capita water availability is low (below 120 liters per capita per day - lcd) and 80% of the water supplied does not meet national water quality standards. In addition, WSCs have been oriented towards using subsidies to meet social targets with minimal incentive to recover costs from user charges. Therefore, billing and collection functions have been neglected. Physical water loss and inadequate billing and collection have combined to yield non-revenue water (NRW)1 of over 50% in some WSCs. 1.7 Urban sanitation facilities have suffered similarly. Sewerage coverage, at 60% of population, is higher in Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) but low in other cities, including Hanoi (30%) . The collection network is in need of extensive repair and treatment of wastewater is non-existent leading to pollution of inner city waterways and groundwater. Solid waste collection in city centers is well organized but disposal suffers from lack of proper landfills. No facilities exist for disposal of hazardous and industrial waste. C. Sectoral Issues 1.8 The objective of rapidly overcoming the overwhelming quantitative and qualitative deficiencies resulting from prolonged under-investment defines the key sectoral problems. These pertain to mobilization of the resources required; formulation of a sector strategy to most effectively utilize available resources and to increase resource mobilization in the future; selection of a sector structure best suited to achieving sector objectives; organization of enterprise management to ensure financial sustainability of investments; and control of construction quality to ensure physical sustainability of the assets provided. Second order issues resulting from the pursuit of rapid sector development pertain to the protection of vulnerable social groups and prevention of negative environmental impacts. 1.9 Concerning mobilization of resources for the sector, it has to be recognized that at present the aggregate requirement of all infrastructure sectors exceeds available resources resulting in allocations for particular sectors that are insufficient to meet total demand. While private capital is flowing to Vietnam, returns in a number of sectors are presently higher than those available in the water supply and sanitation sector. Thus prioritization in the use of available allocated resources and efforts to increase the attractiveness to private capital are important sectoral issues. 1.10 The transition to a market economy in Vietnam gives rise to especially challenging sectoral concerns. Sector policies, strategy, structure and organization 1 Non-revenue water (NRW) refers to the water produced that does not bring in revenue, inter alia, due to losses in the network (leaks), pilferage, non-billing and inaccurate metering.
 3 need to be compatible with an environment changing from a supply to a demand orientation. Presently the most significant steps required pertain to the re- orientation of enterprise management to providing water and sanitation services as a business rather than exclusively as a social obligation, to the gradual replacement of subsidies by user charges, and to the increased ability of enterprises to make rational business decisions without unnecessary political control. At the same time, because of the natural monopoly characteristic of the sector, the role of state agencies needs to evolve into that of regulators rather than providers of service (para 4.1). 1.11 Issues arising from the existence of a sector monopoly in a low-income, market economy need to be anticipated. These pertain to consumer and environmental protection and ensuring universal access in the case of an essential commodity like water. Adequate regulation and tariff design are needed to take care of consumer concerns while project and program planning are needed to cater for environmental consequences of increased water supplies (para 5.3). D. Government Strateqy for the Sector 1.12 Both supply and demand side considerations consequent to economic reforms have led the Government to focus attention on the water sector. Inadequate infrastructure could undermine plans to attract foreign investment and tourism while increased urbanization could overwhelm existing facilities and lead to social dissatisfaction. Proposed environmental legislation requires improvements in water quality and rising incomes and higher user charges increase consumer expectations for better service levels. Thus, resource allocation for both quantitative and qualitative investments is required. 1.13 Based on a UNDP/World Bank Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Study (1990) and a Finnish-funded National Urban Water Supply Strategy (1994), the Government has formulated a two-stage sector development strategy. The first stage focuses on system rehabilitation and renovation to meet demand up to the year 2000 and on institutional strengthening of the WSCs to ensure that the physical investments are sustainable. The second stage would address demand and capacity expansion beyond the year 2000. 1.14 Physical targets in the strategy's first stage call for development in 53 provincial towns to serve 70-80o of their population. Estimated investments to attain these goals would be of the order of US$ 1 billion. This far exceeds the sectoral allocation of the Government. Since, at this stage, the country risks remain too high, individual project size relatively small, and financial returns inadequate to attract substantial private sector investment, the Government has decided to request financing for the key cities targeted for priority development (para 1.4) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for HCMC and IDA for Hanoi, Haiphong, Danang and Quang Ninh; for the other towns it decided to use bilateral low-cost or grant financing contributions as much as available. 1.15 The accompanying institutional strengthening aims to ensure that the physical investments are sustained and operated efficiently. Elements of the strengthening being coordinated with the State Enterprise Reform Program include decentralization of responsibility to the provincial level; increased autonomy for WSCs with elimination of overlapping jurisdictions; re-orientation of WSCs on a more
 4 commercial foundation; increased cost recovery through user charges and gradual elimination of central subsidies. Considerable external development support has also been directed at institutional strengthening of national sector agencies to improve capabilities to plan and prepare sector strategies and projects, to develop policy guidelines, standards and procurement and construction guidelines, and to strengthen project management, implementation and monitoring capacity. 1.16 The Government strategy does include involvement of the private sector through Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) projects for bulk water provision mostly for industrial estates where commercial tariffs are presently considered affordable. However, water provision to urban customers is planned to remain the responsibility of reformed State Enterprises at least in the first stage to the year 2000. E. IDA Strategy and Rationale for Involvement 1.17 The IDA approach formulated in the Country Assistance Strategy2 is in agreement with the Government's two-stage sector development plan which is based on the UNDP/World Bank Sector Study and the National Urban Water Supply Strategy. The CAS identifies poor infrastructure as a key bottleneck to development, transition to a market economy as a prime objective and reform of State Enterprises as an important goal. The CAS states that the Bank would take the lead among donors to help the Government plan and finance infrastructure. Commercialization of the WSCs would also indirectly support the goal of poverty alleviation by redirecting existing subsidies to WSCs for other activities with higher social returns. 1.18 The IDA strategy places greater emphasis on institutional strengthening of the WSCs to ensure that the investments are sustained and operated efficiently and that the sector becomes attractive for private sector participation. However, it is clear that institutional improvements alone are not sufficient to meet the targets for the year 2000. In particular, water services cannot be improved without increasing the capacity and operational efficiency of treatment plants and physical leakages cannot be reduced without major replacement of obsolete tertiary pipelines. In addition, improved revenue collection requires investment in metering of household connections. Thus the IDA strategy is based on a judicious mix of essential physical investments supported by the institutional development necessary to sustain the physical investments. Available documentation confirms that the ADB is also following a similar strategy for its investment in HCM City. 2 Memorandum of the President (Report No. 15053-VN) dated October 25, 1995 and the Progress Report discussed by the Board in conjunction with the proposed credit for a Rural Transport project (IDA/R96-186) on December 23, 1996.
 5 II. SERVICES IN THE PROJECT AREA A. The Project Area 2.1 Based on the Government's regional priorities (para 1.4), the project would include investments in Hanoi, Haiphong, Danang and Halong City/Cam Pha (Quang Ninh province). Hanoi-Haiphong-Quang Ninh form the northern economic triangle and Danang is the focal point for development in central Vietnam. Danang (close to the historic city of Hue) and Halong City (located on Halong Bay, a UNESCO World Heritage site) are also marked for development as tourist attractions. Hanoi, Haiphong and Danang are cities with provincial status. B. Population 2.2 Hanoi is the national capital and second largest municipality after HCM City. Urban population was 1.1 million in 1995 and is expected to reach 1.5 million by 2010. The urban area is projected to grow from 50 km2 in 1990 to 83 km2 in 2010. Haiphong is the main seaport in northern Vietnam and the fourth largest municipality. Urban population was 430,000 in 1995 and is projected to reach 600,000 by 2010. The urban area is 20 km2. Danang, is the major deep-water seaport in central Vietnam with good access to communications networks through National Highway #1 and the Trans-Vietnam railway. It is the third largest municipality in the country. The 1995 urban population of 450,000 is expected to reach 600,000 by 2010. 2.3 Quang Ninh province, the country's principal coal exporter, is situated about 160 km northeast of Hanoi. It is small province with a population of 900,000, of which about 36% (320,000) are urban. The two urban communities, Halong City and Cam Pha, are both important ports. Halong City is the provincial capital; it's western section (Bai Chai) is developing a tourist center separated from the rest of the city by the mouth of the Dien Vong River. Cam Pha lies along the coast to the northeast, about 20 km from Halong City. The combined population of the two cities is expected to grow from 278,000 in 1995 to 500,000 in 2010, mainly by absorbing neighboring districts into an urban agglomeration. C. Water Supply 2.4 Water supply services are provided to domestic, commercial, industrial and institutional consumers by provincial WSCs responsible to the provincial People's Committees (PCs) . In 1995, the Hanoi Water Business Company (WBC) served 900,000 residents (82% of the urban population) and other consumers through 123,000 connections and 1000 standposts. Average production was 320,000 m3/d of which 69% was NRW. Estimated domestic consumption was 120 lcd. The Haiphong WSC served 420,000 residents (98% of the urban population) and the others through 56,000 connections and 650 standposts. Average production was 125,000 m3/d of which about 69% was NRW. The Danang WSC served 191,000 residents (47% of the urban population) and the others through 21,000 connections. Average production was 52,000 m3/d, of which 33% was NRW. The Quang Ninh WSC served 43,200 residents (15% of the urban population) and the others through 13,000 connections. Average production was 28,000 m3/d of which 56% was NRW. 2.5 Of the total connections, 25% are metered in Hanoi, 56% in Haiphong, 100% in Danang and 50% in Quang Ninh. Numerous meters are out of order and many
 6 commercial establishments are registered as domestic consumers qualifying for a lower tariff. Non-metered domestic consumers are billed a fixed monthly charge based on an estimated consumption of 3-6 m3 per capita per month. Non-metered commercial and industrial consumers are charged based on negotiated contracts related to estimated monthly usage. Both situations lead to excessive water use, sharing of connections between families, incentives for meter tampering and leakage of revenue in contracts based on estimation of monthly usage. 2.6 With some exceptions in Hanoi, the condition of water supply facilities is poor and treatment facilities are overloaded. Existing water demand cannot be met, large segments of population must use private, unhygienic wells where groundwater is accessible, and the quality of piped water is below national standards. Tertiary distribution networks have not been developed in any of the cities. They have been replaced by extremely long individual connections (spaghetti connections) that draw water directly from mains. However, these were never pressurized over one bar; also, external and internal corrosion is common, and joints and fittings are leaking, generally beyond repair (see Annex 1 for a detailed description of water supply, sewerage and solid waste services). D. Sewerage. Drainage and Solid Waste 2.7 Sewerage service is provided by the Sewerage and Drainage Companies (SDCs) in Hanoi and Haiphong and Urban Environment Companies (URENCOs) in Danang, Halong City and Cam Pha. In addition to sewerage and drainage, URENCOs manage street cleaning, solid waste collection and disposal, and maintain public toilets, parks and street lights. The SDCs and URENCOs are State Enterprises but unlike WSCs are responsible to municipal and not to provincial PCs. 2.8 The existing drains are combined sewers' serving city centers. They are over 50 years old, built during the French period. Hanoi SDC maintains 120 km of sewers and 35 km of open channels serving about 30% of the urban area; the Haiphong SDC maintains 170 km serving three urban districts; the Danang URENCO maintains 37 km serving about 30% of the urban area and the Halong and Cam Pha URENCOs maintain about 53 km. The systems are overloaded and in poor condition, often flood severely for extended periods, and discharge wastewater without treatment. The population without access to the sewer systems uses on-site sanitation, mostly septic tanks without adequate drain fields. Only about 35%-40% of the solid waste generated is collected. The rest is burned or buried at the source or scattered. The existing landfills do not comply with environmental and health requirements, are mostly filled, and will need to be closed soon. E. Project Demand and Rationale 2.9 In 1991, the Government asked the IDA to help prepare a water supply and sanitation project to remedy the above-mentioned deficiencies in the four cities. The objective of the water supply component was to meet coverage and consumption ' Combined sewers provide the service in one pipe for surface water drainage as well as wastewater, which must first pass through septic tanks (or suitable pre-treatment) to remove solids and toxins before entering the sewer. Separate sewers provide a separate pipe for each service.
 7 targets for the year 2000, improve water quality, rehabilitate facilities, reduce physical leakages and to improve institutional capacity of the WSCs. The objective of the sanitation component was to rehabilitate drainage and sewerage networks, improve flood protection, improve solid waste management, provide new sanitary landfills, and strengthen operating agencies. During preparation, however, it was found that the great number of involved institutions with various financial objectives would make the project very complex (para 3.4) . It was decided, therefore, to reformulate the initial project into a water supply project to be processed first and a sanitation project to follow later. 2.10 Investments in the water supply sector are needed now. Deferred investments have had a negative effect on national development plans and the quality of urban life and further delays would increase the final cost of rehabilitation. Historic funding levels have been low. During 1983-86, urban water supply expenditures were less than 1.5% of the Government's total capital investments, while provincial contributions to water supply projects accounted for 5-7% of total provincial budgets. Allocations increased to 6% of total central Government investment by 1989, but decreased in real terms, from US$ 8.3 million in 1983 to US$ 0.4 million in 1989. Including provincial capital allocations, this corresponded to an overall investment volume of US$ 0.56 million in 1989. Similarly, capital investment levels in sewerage and waste removal in the three major cities was less than US$ 1.5 million by 19922. 2.11 While the low funding partially reflects the low absorptive capacity of the sector, the constraints have been gradually removed. Progressive reforms have delegated more responsibilities to the provinces and increased the autonomy and responsibilities of the WSCs including the ability to borrow for capital expansion. At the same time, the provinces have allowed the WSCs to retain funds that were earlier paid back to the province (e.g., depreciation charges) in order to augment their ability to self-finance their operations. Tariffs have also been increased significantly in real terms and subsidies have been curtailed to move the WSCs towards a more customer and efficiency oriented mode of operation. While institutional reforms need to continue, they have progressed to the stage where project investments in the WSCs are feasible. 2.12 There are no viable project alternatives. From a development perspective, the investment forms an integral part of the overall development of the three key economic regions identified by the Government. From a financing perspective, Government resources are insufficient and private sector investment is not forthcoming at present without tariff increases that would be politically and socially unsustainable3. From an engineering perspective, complete replacement of the run-down systems would be prohibitively expensive and presently unaffordable. Use of development assistance for judicious rehabilitation of existing assets, 2 Historical investments in the sector are reported in "Business Opportunities in Vietnam in the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector," GKW Consult, 1994. The report is available in the project file. 3 The long run marginal cost of water in Hanoi is presently estimated to be more than double the existing average water tariff.
 8 essential capacity expansion and institutional change to increase operational efficiency remains the least cost and most affordable alternative. F. Related Projects and Lessons Learnt 2.13 As a result of low national funding allocations and Vietnam's economic isolation, international counterpart financing in the water sector has been slow. Assistance to the sector since 1985 has not exceeded US$ 100 million. The most significant projects which can yield useful lessons have been financed by.Finnida. The first project in Hanoi is now in its third and final phase with cumulative investment up to 1995 of US$80 million. The second project started in Haiphong in 1990 and cumulative investment has been approximately US$20 million. 2.14 Valuable lessons can be derived from a comparison of the experiences of the two projects. The Hanoi project was started in 1985 before sector reforms were initiated in Vietnam and, as an emergency, was managed by a contractor focusing on physical investments. While significant physical investments have been made in the network and water quality has improved, WBC performance and customer service levels have not shown commensurate improvement. After 10 years, NRW remains above 60%. Lessons from the Hanoi experience have been utilized in the design of the Haiphong project with better results. There has been a greater emphasis on initial engineering preparation and institutional development; the community-based model chosen for system rehabilitation at the neighborhood level has reduced NRW from over 60% to below 40% in the rehabilitated areas. 2.15 However, further explanation is needed for the differences since institutional development efforts initiated in Hanoi since 1990 have not yielded similar results. Part of the reason lies in the nature of the physical systems in the two cities. Hanoi, with easy access to groundwater, has never generated sufficient pressure on the PC or WBC management to change established modes of operation. By contrast, Haiphong with no access to groundwater was faced with acute water scarcity in the summer of 1993 with rioting directed against the WSC resulting in the death of a company employee. As a result, the PC changed the WSC management, and gave a clear mandate to the new Director to show results. The combination of accountability from above and pressure from below provided the driving force for improved performance. These lessons are being incorporated in the project by institutionalizing the two driving forces through annual performance agreements between the PCs and WSCs and public performance audits to increase consumer involvement (paras 4.19 & 4.21). 2.16 Analysis of the Danang WSC confirms the above observations. Acute scarcity of water owing to very limited treatment capacity has forced PC involvement and WSC efficiency in operations. As a result 100% of the connections are metered, disconnection policies are strictly enforced, and billing and collection monitored. As a result NRW is about 33% and performance bonuses from retained earnings yield employee salaries double those in Hanoi. This confirms the assessment that significant improvements can be made to the distribution system and the methods employed for metering, billing and collection, often without major capital expenditure. Therefore, these components are an essential part of the project and the basis for projecting NRW to decrease from over 60% in some WSCs to about 40% by the time steady state conditions are achieved.
 9 2.17 The Hanoi and Haiphong experiences also suggest lessons for the design of institutional and technical assistance components. While this remains a contentious issue, appraisal assessment is that the strategy of seconding long-term advisors as management counterparts without time-bound, task-specific assignments subject to periodic evaluation is not the most cost effective. Lack of a credible option of withdrawing advisors if essential recommendations are not implemented undermines project effectiveness and is ultimately counterproductive. Technical assistance components in the project will be focused on specific, monitorable tasks to be completed within specified time periods. Inclusion of Hanoi in the project was made conditional on the introduction of a credible program to reduce NRW. The PC responded with a concrete measure, signing a contract with an international private water operator to initiate customer management in one supply district. The first phase of the contract is due to be completed in March 1997 and the current results are promising. 2.18 While the project would be the first IDA involvement in the sector and first project to deal with subnational entities, lessons based on the Bank's global experience are incorporated in the project design. The principal lesson is that sector projects should not be used as vehicles to pursue subsidiary objectives at the expense of the main objective. Thus tariffs should not be distorted to satisfy poverty alleviation objectives; instead, direct subsidies should be provided to needy households, if warranted. Similarly, water supply projects should not be used to develop the construction industry if such development affects construction quality. Dividing procurement packages into small contracts with the simplest sub- components (e.g., house and meter connections) reserved for the smallest and least experienced contractors has yielded an extremely expensive lesson. Poor construction of such sub-components results in over 95k of physical leakages which are hard to detect and expensive to repair because the assets are underground. The procurement arrangements for the project have been designed to eliminate such problems. 2.19 Cautionary lessons have been learnt from the experience of the ADB financed project in HCM City. The project which was signed in 1994 was suspended in December 1996 because of slow implementation and disbursement. The project included 33 procurement packages each of which had to be evaluated and separately approved by the Prime Minister. As the first multilateral funded projects at the provincial level in a changing sector environment, it is to be expected that unanticipated new issues would arise during project preparation and implementation that would take time and patience to resolve. 2.20 Another key lesson from the Bank's global experience is to avoid trying to do to much in one project and to refrain from attempting policy or procedural changes that cut across sectors. The project design is not over-ambitious and recognizes that all sector objectives cannot be achieved in one project because of the constraints imposed by the realities on the ground (first time borrower, first project dealing directly with State Enterprises at the sub-national level, a transition economy in which sector policies are not firmly established, provincial and enterprise management relatively unfamiliar with the requirements of market- based operations, low staff salaries, consumer affordability considerations, limited counterpart funds, limited debt service capability and limited absorptive capacity). Therefore, the project has been designed as part of a careful, phased strategy structured around an investment program comprising in the four cities at least two separate water supply and sanitation projects each. The first water supply project
 10 includes measures that are most critical and yield the greatest immediate benefits while setting in motion policy reforms and actions that would ensure the successful attainment of all objectives by the completion of the investment program. However, reform of generic problems cutting across sectors such as unsystematic loan processing procedures or cumbersome funds flow arrangements at the country level are not and cannot be addressed through the project.
 11 III. THE PROJECT A. Project Oriqin and History 3.1 The Government's goal with respect to urban water supply and sanitation is to improve the quality of drinking water and waste water, to develop infrastructure to meet defined targets and to commercialize the operating companies. To achieve these objectives, it has sought external financing. In 1991, it requested IDA funding for a water supply and sanitation project in four major cities and secured bilateral assistance to prepare the project from Finland (for Hanoi and Haiphong), Denmark (for Quang Ninh) and Australia (for Danang). 3.2 Project processing was held up till 1993 because of delays in signing agreements between the Government and bilateral donors. Project reviews in 1993 identified project complexity as a major risk since water supply, sewerage and sanitation services are provided by different companies with different funding arrangements. However, it was decided to proceed with the project design on the grounds that the Ministry of Construction (MOC), responsible for urban water supply and sanitation at the national level, would coordinate the project components. As part of project preparation, technical assistance was arranged from Australian aid to strengthen the regulatory capacity of the MOC. 3.3 However, in 1995, further to the decentralization of sector responsibilities to the provincial level, the Government decided that MOC would remain actively responsible for managing projects only in secondary cities. Major cities, which included those in the IDA-assisted project, would be directly responsible for their projects. While institutionally this constituted a step in the right direction, freeing the WSCs from parallel chains of command, operationally it resulted in the project design becoming unmanageable. 3.4 As a result, it was agreed to divide the initial project into two, a water supply project, to be processed first and a sanitation project to follow later, and to outline a sector investment program for the four cities as follows: (a) Water Supply Project to be implemented in 1997 to rehabilitate existing facilities and meet demand up to 2000; (b) Sanitation Project to be implemented in 1999 to restore functionality of existing sewerage and drainage facilities, to provide septic tank maintenance program and to improve solid waste management including construction of sanitary landfills; (c) Second Water Supply Project to be implemented from 2000 to expand capacity to meet demand up to 2010; and (d) Second Sanitation Project to be implemented in 2002 to expand wastewater collection and treatment to handle the increased water production resulting from the Second Water Supply Project. The sanitation projects would exclude sewerage and drainage in Hanoi which is being funded by OECF of Japan and possibly solid waste management. Both the Second Water Supply Project and the Second Sanitation Project would be prepared within the respective first projects. B. Objectives and Design 3.5 The aims of the first water supply project in the four cities are to: (a) improve the quality of water supply services in Hanoi, Haiphong, Quang Ninh and Danang through renovation of existing facilities in order to satisfy demand up to 2000 of about 2.5 million people in the cities; (b) ensure sustainability
 12 of the physical investments by developing the institutional capabilities of water supply agencies, facilitating their commercialization, and upgrading their staff skills through training; and (c) assist in preparation of a future investment program to satisfy water demand after 2000. 3.6 At the present time, a project based on concessional financing, maximum rehabilitation of existing facilities, limited capacity expansion and concentrated institutional improvements is the dominant, least cost alternative. Government resources are insufficient and private investment is not forthcoming in distribution of essential services because of unfavorable risk/return characteristics. Large scale replacement of existing facilities is unaffordable since tariff increases to meet full cost recovery are only possible in a graduated manner because of social and political implications. 3.7 To ensure that the selection of engineering sub-components conformed to the specific needs and preferences of the individual cities, the following mechanism was adopted. Based on an initial assessment of the financial capacity of the WSCs, an investment envelope was allocated to the WSC. The WSCs, in collaboration with engineering consultants, identified alternative sub-components to meet given project objectives (coverage, consumption and quality targets) which were assigned weights depending upon the specific situation of each city. Sub-components were ranked based on their overall impact measured in terms of expected contribution to each target weighted by the importance of the target. The rankings, made independently by consultants and WSCs, were discussed in a meeting attended by members of the provincial administration, and the highest ranked sub-components within the investment envelope were included in the project. The remaining sub-components were deferred for consideration in the follow-up project. This procedure ensured that the selection of sub-components was made in a participatory manner and that the project is optimally sized, not too large to be financially unsustainable by the WSCs and not too small to fall short of essential targets. C. Description 3.8 The project would include the following elements: (a) renewal and upgrading of water supply facilities in the urban districts of Hanoi, Haiphong and Danang, and Halong/Cam Pha in Quang Ninh province; (b) institutional measures to ensure sustainability of the physical investments; (c) support activities consisting of various studies, advisory services, supervision of construction and training; and (d) resettling and rehabilitating the population affected by the project. The project locations are shown on maps IDA Nos 28592 through 28595 and a detailed description is provided in Annex 2. 3.9 The renewal and upgrading of water supply facilities would include the following: In Hanoi, (a) production wells and two treatment plants; (b) primary, secondary and tertiary distribution networks, including large water meters; and (c) new water connections, replacement of existing connections made of galvanized steel (GS) pipe and provision of water meters. In Haiphong, (a) a raw water pumping station and raw water transmission main; (b)
 13 a treatment plant; (c) primary and secondary distribution pipelines, including a balancing reservoir; (d) a tertiary distribution network in 17 wards (phuongs) with water connections and provision of water meters; and (e) equipment, materials and vehicles for operations and maintenance. In Danang, (a) a water intake, transmission main and access road; (b) a treatment plant and reservoir; (c) a treated water transmission main, primary, secondary and tertiary distribution network with connections and provision of water meters; and (d) equipment, materials and vehicles for operations and maintenance. In Quang Ninh, (a) deep wells; (b) raw water transmission and raw water pumping stations; (c) two treatment plants; (d) transmission and primary distribution mains; (e) a secondary and tertiary distribution network with connections and provision of water meters, booster pumping stations and water reservoirs; and (f) equipment, materials and vehicles for operations and maintenance. 3.10 Institutional measures in WSCs would include: (a) upgrading the accounts receivable systems; (b) improving customer management (mapping, registration, disconnections-reconnections, etc.); and (c) preparation of O&M guidelines for each WSC as a basis for establishing adequate budget allocations which is an essential condition for upgrading of operation and maintenance procedures to sustainable levels; (d) corporate planning models. 3.11 Support activities would include construction management and various studies concerning (a) the quality of surface water sources, evaluating monitored data, and identifying actions aimed at protecting the sources against pollution; (b) identifying, quantifying, monitoring and evaluating NRW; (c) periodic audit of the safety of Cao Van dam in Quang Ninh (para 3.33) and introducing corrective actions, and (d) staff training and professional evaluation of managers and operators in collaboration with international private water system operators. TORs for the institutional components would be formulated following the mid-term review of the first water supply project. D. Environmental Impact 3.42 Implementation of the project would be beneficial for the living standards and health conditions of the local population. Rehabilitation of the existing facilities would reduce NRW while the expansion of treatment plants and transmission and distribution lines would improve the quality and volume of water, enhance service levels and raise revenues. 3.43 Negative impacts would include the acquisition of cultivated land, demolition of structures and inconvenience for the residents during construction. To mitigate these effects, the project would include environmental monitoring, which would continue during implementation. Land compensation would be paid according to the RAPs. Other compensations would be made to government agencies (where their property is affected) during the construction of water mains and distribution networks. 3.44 Temporary and manageable impacts during site clearing and construction of the facilities would include increased levels of traffic, dust, and noise; disruption of water supply; blocked drainage and water pollution due to soil erosion at excavation sites; and disposal of surplus soil and construction materials. The impacts on residential areas would be minor since most of the WTPs, intakes, and other facilities would be situated away from residential areas. The mountainous area in Quang Ninh where the raw water main would be laid and the hill in Danang where the WTP would be constructed are degraded areas and serious impacts on the local ecology are not expected. 3.45 In close consultation with the residents, the pipeline would be laid along road shoulders where the impacts on households and businesses would be minimal. During the design phase of the water mains and distribution pipelines, efforts were made to minimize the impacts on burial grounds, houses, and buildings, the need to obtain land and to excavate large quantities of soil. 3.46 The contractors would be required to carry out the planning and construction according to contractual environmental specifications, including (a) consultations with residents, (b) provision of safe temporary paths for residents and businesses, (c) safety measures for the public and workers, (d) measures to reduce erosion, dust, and noise levels due to construction, (e) limited transport and construction along the main roads in urban areas during rush hours and in residential areas at night, (f) appropriate disposal of surplus soil and construction materials, and (g) provision of adequate water by alternate means when piped water is interrupted. 3.47 Once operating, the WTPs would generate treatment sludge which would be disposed of in retention lagoons in WTPs and, when dried, would be disposed of in controlled landfills. Significant net increase of water supply is not anticipated in the first project. The increased system capacity would displace water from alternative sources being used by residents not presently served by the piped system. Significant capacity expansion is planned for the second water supply project. By that time, the first sanitation project currently being
 24 prepared in the four cities (para 3.4) would have been implemented. 3.48 Potential impacts on land subsidence in Hanoi, dam safety in Quang Ninh, salinity intrusion in Danang, and contamination of water quality at the intakes and in the water supply systems in all project components have been identified and will be addressed by the project's implementation support.  26 IV. THE INSTITUTIONAL ANALYSIS A. Sector Structure 4.1 The Ministry of Construction (MOC) is the main national agency responsible for water supply and sanitation. Through its departments and enterprises, the MOC prepares national plans for the sector, regulates various technical aspects of water and sanitation facilities, approves designs of major projects, and assists in the implementation of water supply and sanitation projects. In addition, it has wide responsibilities in areas of construction, construction supervision and investment. 4.2 As part of decentralization, the responsibility for operating public utilities, including water supply, was assigned to provinces with elimination of MOC's direct involvement. PCs created Water Supply Companies (WSCs) as legal entities1 to be responsible for construction, operation and maintenance of urban water supply. The PCs have considerable influence on WSCs development policies, including increased market orientation, setting targets for production and distribution of water, deciding on WSCs financial policies, including the blend of tariffs and subsidies. The organization structure of a typical Provincial Government is shown in Chart 2. At negotiations assurances were obtained that the Government would cause the PCs to take all actions to enable the respective WSCs to implement the project and comply with their obligations. 4.3 Water supply services in the project cities are managed and operated by WSCs which report to the respective PCs. The organization structure of a typical WSC is shown in Chart 3. 4.4 The optimal sector structure for provision of urban water supply services in Vietnam has been evaluated under an ADB financed technical assistance. A number of alternatives including a national water supply company and municipal companies were assessed but the existing structure based on provincial WSCs was considered to offer the best potential for sector development. The appraisal mission concurs with this recommendation. The sector structure for provision of sewerage and sanitatiLon services would be reviewed in detail as part of the preparation of the sanitation project. B. Project Implementation 4.5 The project would be implemented in each province by the provincial water company: the Hanoi Water Business Company (WBC), the Haiphong Water Supply Company, the Quang Ninh Water Supply Company and the Danang Water Supply Company. To aid implementation the WSCs have established Component Implementation Committees (CICs) with the participation of the provincial PC. CICs are headed by the Deputy Director of the Transport and Urban Public Works Service (TUPWS) of the PC responsible for water supply in Hanoi, Haiphong and Danang and by the Director of the Construction Department (CD) of the PC in Quang Ninh. CICs, 1 Details of establishing WSCs as legal entities with separate legal personality are included in the project's legal documents.
 27 supported by CMCs (para 3.21), would help the WSCs implement the works by facilitating processing of various administrative actions within the PC including budgetary planning and financial support. The CIC of each component would also help the WSC evaluate various institutional and other studies, assist in implementing proposed institutional improvements within the WSCIs organization, and advise on content of annual plans for implementation support and training activities to be provided through Finnish, Danish and Australian technical assistance (para 3.23) . The implementing arrangements are shown schematically in Chart 1. An understanding was reached at negotiations that the CIC would be maintained for the duration of the project. C. Staffing and Training 4.6 In 1995, the number of employees was 1,720 in Hanoi, 627 in Haiphong, 476 in Quang Ninh and 274 in Danang. Employees per 1,000 connections varied from about 11 in Haiphong and Danang to 14 in Hanoi and 35 in Quang Ninh. Primarily due to the projected rise in the number of connections, the ratio is expected to stabilize below 10 by 2000 in all four cities which is acceptable and within parameters of major Asian cities2. 4.7 Staff salaries conform to the general scales set by the Ministry of Labor, but bonuses are also paid for achieving certain financial targets; thus, income levels are affected by company performance. For example, since Hanoi 's WBC has operated at a loss in recent years, salaries have been considerably lower than in Danang and Haiphong, and top-quality employees have been hard to retain. Those that stay often have to find additional work to meet their family needs. 4.8 Training levels also vary among the four companies, mainly due to the resources available and management interest. In Hanoi and Haiphong, training has been supported by the on-going Finnish Program. During this time, 188 staff from the Hanoi WBC participated in overseas training or study tours, although some left the company later, and in Haiphong, 17 staff participated in overseas study tours. In September 1995, Haiphong WSC entered into a twinning-training agreement with the water company in Turku, Finland and the Asian Institute of Technology will train 11 Hanoi WBCs managers during 1996. In Quang Ninh and Danang, resources have not been available for management training. 4.9 All four WSCs companies recruit technicians such as welders, electricians and plumbers who are formally trained in national or provincial vocational schools. However, those working specifically in water trades (such as pump operators, pipe fitters and meter readers, etc.) are trained in-house. The training is provided by company engineers and technicians using course material prepared by the company and normally results in examinations and improved salary grades of trainees. However, a shortage of funds for training, lack of training aids such as equipment and tools, as well as standard curricula and evaluation methods adversely affects the quality and output of training. 4.10 The analysis of training needs to meet the long-term manpower 2 Water Utilities Data Book, Asian and Pacific Region; ADB, November 1993.
 28 requirements of the sector has not yet been made, mainly due to the perceived view in the Government that decentralization of the training to WSCs is the correct approach and that the training of operating staff without providing means for physical improvement of degraded facilities has low value. While the idea has some merit, it is recognized that a study of human resource development for the sector, including policies to resolve various related issues such as national licensing of sector trade categories, salary scales, performance incentives, etc. should be initiated in the near future. 4.11 Experience suggests that the lead time required for carrying out such a study would exceed the time required to bring the physical components of the project on line. Project-related training, therefore, to upgrade skills of most critical trade categories in shortest time was found the most feasible solution at this time. Greater regional exposure for managers and specialized training in commercially oriented systems is also proposed. Along these lines a training needs assessment has been completed for all WSCs and a training proposal has being prepared in collaboration with the private water operator Saur International (SI) (para 3.14). D. Institutional Issues 4.12 Key institutional issues pertain to facilitating the transition of the WSCs from subsidized entities operating in a planned environment and providing a minimum level of social service to commercial companies in a market economy accountable to owners and consumers and self-financing operations and capital expansion through user charges. Although, as part of the State Enterprise Reform, the WSCs are expected to recover all operating and maintenance expenditures by 2000 and contribute to capital expenditures subsequently, the organizational structure, operating rules and management style required to support these changes have been slow to evolve. Thus, the WSCs are quite some distance from their goals of financial independence and customer orientation. However, the commitment of the provincial PCs and the motivation of the WSC management to be ready for the transition to the market economy leaves no doubt that the changes are achievable. 4.13 The principal changes needed by the WSCs relate to increased operational autonomy, customer orientation, commercial procedures, financial planning and the institutionalization of accountability and performance enhancing incentive systems. Implementation of the changes is modulated by the very real and immediate need to increase revenues quickly. Increased revenues are required to appropriately fund operations and maintenance, compensate staff adequately and service the debt for capital expenditures. Increased revenues are also needed to eliminate subsidies and gradually transform the WSCs into entities operating on commercial basis. 4.14 In 1995, the Hanoi PC made a credible commitment to reducing NRW by entering into a technical assistance contract with SI to implement a customer management program in one district of Hanoi. The first phase of the contract would be completed in March 1997. A connections survey and inventory of 4328 customers was completed in September 1996. The survey showed that of the 4328 customers, 845 were unidentified in the WSC records, 114 were illegal, and 632 were not receiving any water. This survey indicates the potential for increasing
 29 revenues through commercial customer management. 4.15 A decentralized management model based on fully metered zones operated with community participation is being progressively implemented in Haiphong since 1995 with good results. NRW in the improved zones has fallen from over 60% to below 40%. The entire system will be converted to the new model under the IDA financed project. The Hanoi WBC has agreed on a NRW reduction program with the Hanoi PC and is implementing it using a similar approach. Comparable results have been reported in the pilot zones. 4.16 In parallel to the above, accounting consultants Coopers and Lybrand conducted an evaluation of the billing and collection procedures and accounts receivable system of the Hanoi WBC in 1995 and made recommendations for improvement. Based on the study, a Japanese Grant has been obtained for the Haiphong WSC to improve billing and collection procedures and the account receivables system. Coopers and Lybrand was selected for the Haiphong contract and commenced work in January 1997. Similar work would be initiated in Quang Ninh and Danang with bilateral assistance. Once the accounting systems are computerized and fully converted to the new national accounting standards, corporate planning and financial models are proposed to be introduced to facilitate planning for capital investment programs. 4.17 In Hanoi and Haiphong, pilot NRW detection and evaluation programs are included in the technical assistance. Based on the asset inventory and revaluation completed by all WSCs at the end of 1995, operation and maintenance guidelines based on standard engineering codes of practice are to be prepared to ensure appropriate budget allocations for the purpose. 4.18 The above initiatives designed to generate the surplus required to underpin the sustainability of the physical investments would be complemented by training needed to manage, operate and maintain the facilities effectively in a market economy. A training needs assessment has been completed for each WSC and a proposal for a pilot training and evaluation program for the Hanoi WBC has been prepared in collaboration with SI. It is proposed that based on the evaluation of the pilot program, the training center in Hanoi be raised to the level of a national center for training of staff from other WSCs. Training needs of the WSCs would be identified and evaluated on an annual basis and financed from bilateral assistance. 4.19 Measures to increase WSC operational autonomy while making the companies more accountable to the PCs would be based on the introduction of annual performance agreements between the PCs and the WSCs. Such agreements have been introduced in Thailand with Bank assistance as part of public sector reform. Given the natural monopoly in water distribution and the fact that significant private sector involvement is not yet possible, this constitutes a feasible option to improve public sector performance. At present, embryonic agreements related to reduction of NRW exist in Hanoi and a few other WSCs. 4.20 The introduction of other targets in performance agreements between the PCs and WSCs would integrate project monitoring and evaluation into the management incentive system in a dynamic fashion. While it is recognized that the monetary rewards in terms of bonus payments resulting from such a system may not
 30 initially compare favorably to other sources of additional income, the system would allow the WSCs' performance to be compared on a common basis providing strong psychological motivation for management to improve company performance. However, the introduction is intended to be selective, based on a judgement of when such arrangements would yield positive results without becoming bureaucratized. 4.21 Management incentives to improve performance via consumer involvement are proposed to be institutionalized through the introduction of public performance audits (PPAs) of the WSCs by an independent agency. Public disclosure of comparative information relevant for users would enable consumer voice and benchmarking competition to be used as effective tools in improving WSC performance. PPAs are being introduced in the Philippines with Bank assistance. 4.22 Given the decision to reduce sectoral coordination at the national government level, the Association of Water Supply Companies (AWSC) is currently being strengthened to share experiences and best practices among the WSCs. For example, the Danang WSC management has succeeded in universal metering and in getting NRW down to 33% while the Haiphong WSC has implemented a system of community involvement in managing water at the neighborhood level which has decreased NRW from over 60% to below 40% in rehabilitated wards. This lends confidence to the expectation that the potential exists to reduce NRW quickly and relatively inexpensively in all WSCs. A workshop on commercial management of water supply companies in a market economy has been requested by the AWSC and is planned for August 1997 in collaboration with EDI. 4.23 Sector dialogue with the Government is continuing on gradual private sector participation in the operations of the WSCs. Evaluation of the experience gained during the implementation of the contract between Hanoi WBC and SI and BOT schemes for bulk water provision would be used to propose suitable modifications and extensions.
 31 V. FINANCIAL ANALYSIS A. Rate Structure 5.1 Country-wide water tariffs for residential customers, state organizations and businesses were maintained up to 1986 at the nominal rate of 1 VND/m3. Since then, they have been increased significantly in real terms, following the Government's decision to charge users instead of covering all costs through general taxes'. In the early 1990s, the tasks of supplying water and setting tariffs were decentralized, and provincial WSCs were created that were expected to progressively become financially self-sufficient. Since then, the WSCs have submitted every year tariff proposals, including an analysis of customer affordability, to the PCs for approval. Currently, most customers are charged on the basis of metered consumption; non-metered residential customers are charged on assumed monthly consumption (usually 4 m3 per capita) and industrial-commercial customers through negotiated contracts. 5.2 From 1990-1995, tariffs in the project cities have increased unevenly. The average tariff in Quang Ninh is the highest, VND 1,800/m3 in 1995, compared to VND 1,420/m3 in Hanoi, VND 1,150/m3 in Haiphong and VND 838/m3 in Danang. Typically, domestic consumers pay 20% less than the average charge per m3, while commercial consumers pay about 45% above the average. Each city has several categories (domestic, commercial and tourist facilities), with separate rates. In Hanoi and Danang, tariffs include a 10% surcharge for sewerage. About 1,000 public taps operate in Hanoi, and 650 in Haiphong. These provide free water in low-income areas, but will be gradually phased out. All four WSCs have received approvals from respective PCs for increased tariffs in 1996 at or above the rate used in the financial projections (projections use 1995 as the base year as it is the last full year for which complete accounts are available) for the IDA financed project. 5.3 A national water tariff policy study financed by the ADB was completed in March 1996 and its recommendations are presently being reviewed by the Government. The appraisal mission is in agreement with these recommendations which also address issues of consumer protection and universal access. They include a minimum monthly charge (covering 5 m3 for domestic and 10 m3 for non-domestic customers), a lifeline block2 (varying between 12 and 20 m3/month depending on city size set at a minimum of 1,500 VND/m3), a progressive tariff with three tariff bands, and a separate tariff for industrial and commercial customers. The recommendations also include universal metering, amortization of connection costs through the monthly tariff and groundwater licensing. At negotiations assurances were obtained from the Government that necessary actions would be taken through PCs, including adjustment of water tariffs, to achieve required financial objectives of Hanoi WBC and Haiphong, Danang and Quang Ninh WSCs. I For the Hanoi WBC, domestic tariff increased 50 times over the period 1988-1995, starting from 20 VND/m3. During the same period, price of electricity to the company increased 12 times while average company salary increased 14 times. 2 Specific problem related to apartment blocks equipped with one water meter is taken into consideration.
 32 5.4 The study estimates the average incremental financial cost (as a proxy for long run marginal cost) in Hanoi to be VND 2,867/m3 and concludes, based on an affordability analysis, that tariffs cannot be raised to this level immediately but would have to converge to the full cost over a period of more than five years. The study recommends an average 1997 tariff in Hanoi of VND l,910/m3 which is considered affordable based on an accepted 4% of household income affordability criterion. The average tariff implemented in Hanoi in mid-1996 is VND 1,700/m3 which is in line with the study recommendations. B. Accounting and Auditing 5.5 The Ministry of Finance (MF) is responsible for issuing guidelines and standards on the accounting and financial management of state organizations. WSCs budget requests and reports are submitted through the TUPWS or CD to the PCs. The finance department of each WSC uses cash-based accounting; it prepares monthly or quarterly accounts using the recently introduced national standard accounting system which supports cost-centered analysis of expenditures. Year-end accounts are currently audited by the PCs, but MF requires that independent auditors be appointed in all cities during 1997. These auditors will have to be confirmed to be acceptable to IDA. The WSCs will maintain the project accounts. 5.6 Hanoi WBC accounts were partly computerized from 1993-1995, and are organized into internal cost accounting units covering the treatment plants and distribution enterprises. The program to complete the computerization and transfer existing accounts to the new system is underway. The computerized billing and collection system will be reviewed under the project and upgraded where necessary to include control accounts. 5.7 Haiphong WSC manually prepared cash-based accounts through to 1995. In 1996, under a Finnish-funded water supply and sanitation program, accounts are being computerized and a management accounting and information system introduced to support institutional development and help the managers effectively run the company. A new computerized billing and collection and accounts receivable system will be introduced under the project. 5.8 Quang Ninh WSC uses a manual general ledger system of accounts, with transactions recorded on a cash basis. The project's technical assistance program will upgrade the accounting and management information system and transfer manual accounts to a computerized accrual-based system that uses an internal cost and profit center analysis. It will begin in 1997 and be completed in 2-3 years. 5.9 Danang WSC's accounts are fully computerized using data base software. Under the project, a technical assistance program would review the system to ensure all accounting controls and internal cost accounting units are established, and that results comply with internationally recognized accounting standards. 5.10 During negotiations, assurances were obtained that the annual financial statements of the Hanoi WBC, Haiphong WSC, Quang Ninh WSC, and Danang WSC would be audited by firms acceptable to the IDA and submitted to the IDA within nine months of the close of each fiscal year. The Government would maintain the Statement of Expenditures and the special accounts for the ITF credit and Danish Trust Fund, and audit reports which would include separate opinions on these Statements, would be
 33 prepared by firms acceptable to the IDA and submitted to the IDA within nine months of the close of each fiscal year. It was agreed that because current accounting systems and procedures are not capable of readily producing financial statements in accordance with internationally accepted standards or principles and the fact that the statements have not been audited in the past, the first audit reports would be due by September 1999 and would include audits of the companies' accounts for FY98 and project accounts only for FY97. C. Billing and Collections 5.11 In Hanoi, the WBC's district water enterprises read meters (25W of registered connections are metered) and send the results to headquarters. Monthly bills are prepared centrally and include a 10% charge for sewerage. In 1995, there were 128,000 registered customers, but partly due to administrative weaknesses, only about 90,000 bills were issued each month. Payment is due within one month of the billing. Accounts receivable at the end of 1995 were equal to 68 days' sales. The bad debt provision for 1995 was 2% of gross sales, and the same figure was included in financial projections through 2004. 5.12 About 44% of Haiphong's WSC connections are unmetered. The billing system is computerized and uses data-base software, but does not include accounting controls or a ledger. Customers are given 10 days to pay, and service is disconnected after 20 days of non-payment. A Japanese Grant-financed technical assistance to be implemented by the Haiphong WSC in 1997/1998 will design and introduce a new computerized accounting software module for the billing, collection and accounts receivable ledger. The new system will have adequate controls and will be designed to interface with the general ledger. 5.13 Although over half the connections in Quang Ninh WSC are un-metered, meter readers visit every connection once a month and manually prepare the bills and collect the fees based on the meter data or number of occupants. The WSC recognizes the system is unsatisfactory and needs to computerize the system. Thus, the technical assistance under the project will make this issue a priority. 5.14 All of Danang WSC's connections are metered and read every month and customers are given 20 days to pay their bills. The billing system is computerized, using data base software, but does not include proper accounting controls. The system will be reviewed and upgraded through the technical assistance program provided under the project. D. Fixed Assets and Revaluation 5.15 Until early 1995, fixed assets held by WSCs were owned by the PCs and the depreciation charge was transferred partly or totally to the PCs, depending on their share of investment funding. Thus, the WSCs were not responsible for financing major replacements or new investments. To ensure that WSCs would self- finance capital works and meet their debt service obligations, the Government decided in 1995 to abolish the remittance of depreciation charges. 5.16 WSCs maintain registers for assets used in water operations, including depreciation, over the estimated life expectancy. All the WSCs updated inventories of fixed assets as of December 31, 1995, and these valuations have been used to
 34 adjust financial projections. The book value of fixed assets is projected to increase each year by the annual inflation rate. E. Past Financial Performance 5.17 The WSCs' recent financial performance in the project cities has been unsatisfactory. In some, the companies appeared to cover a number of recurrent or capital costs, but depreciation was considerably understated. Also, maintenance was inadequate, which meant that true operating costs were not reflected on the income statements. Further, the PCs had continually subsidized the WSCs for new construction and major repairs, even as the water supply systems deteriorated and water losses increased. Since the end of 1994 programs for corrective actions leading to elimination of subsidies have been introduced in Hanoi and Haiphong and evidence from Haiphong indicates improving tendencies. F. The analysis is presented in Annex 12. 5.35 The base year is taken as 1995, the last year for which actual data is available. Without the project, operating efficiency would deteriorate significantly due to ageing of already obsolete equipment. While this would be non-linear and discontinuous, a linear approximation of a half percent real annual increase in operating costs is used in the analysis to reflect all the impacts of the deterioration. The 1995 tariff is assumed to remain constant in real terms since there would be no justification for tariff increases without the project. Even if tariffs are increased, real revenues are likely to remain unchanged because consumers would disconnect from the utility and resort to self-provisioning in the face of deteriorating service. In the "with project" scenario, O&M expenditures, tariffs and percentage of water billed are assumed to increase as indicated in Annex 10. Efficiency gains that would result from lower per unit electricity consumption are ignored. The FIRRs are calculated over 20 years and a 50% salvage value is assumed. 5.36 The FIRRs are dependant on the projected tariff and NRW estimates which have therefore been forecast conservatively. In Hanoi, for example, average tariff per m3 is projected to increase from VND 1,420 in 1995 gradually to VND 2,213 in 1999, VND 3,331 in 2002 and VND 4,796 in 2004 yielding a total increase of 238% over the period 1995-2004. The proposed tariff increase needs to be seen in reference to a domestic tariff increase in Hanoi of 4900% during the period 1988-1995 (para 5.1) 5.37 NRW in Hanoi, for example, is projected to decrease from 69% in 1995 to 51% by 1999, 48% by 2002 and 46% by 2004. Given the findings of the customer management survey conducted in Hanoi by Saur International (para 4.14), the decrease of NRW in rehabilitated wards in Haiphong from 70% to 30* within three years and an existing NRW of 33% in Danang, these targets are considered very reasonable. However, continuing attention would need to be devoted to these parameters because of the sensitivity of the FIRR to variations in them. 5.38 The sensitivity analysis reported in Annex 12 (Table A 12.5) shows that the FIRR for the project falls from 16% to 13% if the tariff increase falls 10% below forecasted values; to 15t if NRW reduction is 10% less than estimated; and to 14.5% if there is a 10% over run in capital costs. However, standard analysis assumes no pent up demand, no change in the quality of the product and no hidden expenditures asides from the price charged. Secondly, the water to be provided after the project would be qualitatively different compared to that available presently both in terms of quality and service level; willingness to pay for potable water at a higher service level is greater than existing charges.
