 41 VI. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION A. Proiect Benefits 6.1 The proposed project in Hanoi, Haiphong, Quang Ninh and Danang aims to: (a) rehabilitate and expand facilities to meet coverage, consumption and quality targets for the year 2000; (b) improve institutional capacity and operational efficiency of the WSCs to sustain the physical investments; and (c) prepare an investment and institutional development program to satisfy system demands after 2000 with maximum self-financing and private sector participation. 6.2 The project is part of the Government's plan to upgrade all infrastructure in three key economic regions in order to remove constraints to industrial development and tourism, to meet demands due to increased urbanization and rising incomes, to meet environmental standards and to provide access to safe drinking water. Hanoi, Haiphong and Quang Ninh are part of the northeastern economic triangle and Danang is the designated growth center in central Vietnam. Hanoi, Haiphong and Danang have been identified for priority development as industrial and commercial centers to absorb foreign direct investment while Danang and Halong City in Quang Ninh province are designated for development as major tourist attractions. 6.3 Project contributions to development of industrial, commercial and tourism potential in the cities would translate into benefits resulting in higher urban incomes and property values. Better service levels in terms of system reliability, continuous supply and higher pressure would eliminate household expenditures on storage tanks and electric motors designed to compensate for poor service. Improved quality of drinking water which presently does not meet national standards would eliminate household expenditures incurred on boiling water which is a necessity in Vietnam. In addition, improved water quality would reduce health expenditures resulting from the prevalence of water borne diseases. Households presently without access to piped water would realize time and money savings when recourse to vendors or wells would be made unnecessary in addition to health benefits from the availability of potable water. Industrial and commercial establishments currently pumping groundwater would not need to do so resulting in environmental benefits. 6.4 Institutional development aimed at commercializing the water companies would attract private investment in the sector and increase the ability of the companies to self-finance future capital expenditure. Both outcomes would reduce the need for public subsidies which could yield higher social benefits in other sectors. 6.5 Without the project, the deterioration of physical assets which have suffered from prolonged lack of maintenance would accelerate. Equipment life would be reduced, efficiency would decline, operating costs would increase, the quality of water would deteriorate, more outages would occur and more consumers would disconnect from the system, providing water for themselves. Water scarcities would result given the increasing urban population. The possibility of water riots cannot be ruled out; such riots directed against the water company occurred in Haiphong in 1993 resulting in the death of a company employee. The Government's infrastructure package for the key economic regions would remain incomplete and ability of the cities to attract foreign investment and tourism would be negatively affected. Construction of facilities for tourists in a number of cities is already on hold
 42 because of water and power shortages. B. Least-Cost Solution 6.6 The Government's commitment to the project is not explicitly based on a project rate of return analysis because a number of strategic social, development, environmental and health objectives cannot be quantified precisely in terms of benefits. There is no alternative to meeting, at the very least, the minimum consumption requirements of the urban population, preferably with an acceptable quality of water. Consequently, the Government's objective is to attain a minimum defined level of coverage, consumption, service, and water quality by 2000 in the major urban centers at the least cost. The alternative options evaluated are detailed in the feasibility studies which are available in the project file. Out of these, the least cost alternatives have been selected for the project. C. Rate of Return 6.7 Notwithstanding the above, based on partial quantification of benefits and costs and conservative assumptions, economic rates of return have been calculated for the project components. The financial internal rates of return, reported in para 5.34, are used as the starting point to compute the economic internal rates of return. 6.8 To convert financial costs to economic costs, taxes and duties have been eliminated. The relatively free exchange rate implies that there is no significant foreign exchange premium. The major operating cost is due to electricity, comprising more than half of total operating costs, which is being charged to the WSCs at the long run marginal cost of electricity without any distortion. Regarding local wage costs, it has been determined that market (or financial) wage rates broadly reflect the opportunity cost of skilled labor in Vietnam taking into account the increasing shortage of qualified technical staff. Although minimum wage levels may distort wage rates for unskilled labor somewhat above market levels, the more skilled labor force which predominates in the WSCs is likely to be virtually unaffected. With respect to unskilled labor, a shadow wage factor of 0.6 is proposed. However, sensitivity analysis indicates that the impact is insignificant since labor costs are a small proportion of total supply costs. The prices of treatment chemicals are reported to be distorted but again this is a small proportion and is ignored. Rather, the impacts of labor and chemical cost distortions are captured through sensitivity of the results to total costs. Net present value is calculated using a real discount rate of 10%. 6.9 The only benefits quantified for inclusion in the economic analysis relate to the coping costs consumers would avoid because of the project. Earlier research has shown that water tariff is not the only cost borne by consumers. Rather, the inefficiencies of water supply companies are passed on in terms of extra costs to consumers who attempt to improve their service by installing underground and overhead storage tanks and operate electric motors to pump water or use backup devices like handpumps. Also, they incur additional expenses to purify the water
 43 by boiling or using filters'. Data from HCM City indicates that households connected to the water supply system incur additional costs of 300,000 VND per month. Households without access to the piped system incur even higher costs since the price of water purchased from vendors exceeds the price of piped water. 6.10 Full benefits of avoided coping costs are unlikely to be realized immediately since they are dependent on changes in consumer behavior and confidence in the reliability of the improved service which will build up gradually. In the "with project" scenario, it is assumed that household avoided costs of 33,000 VND per month would start being realized in 1999 and would stabilize at 45,000 VND per month in 2001. 6.11 Benefits resulting from improved health and environment, higher incomes and property values due to the development impact of improved water service, and availability of piped water to non-domestic users presently relying on groundwater are ignored in the analysis. Therefore, the rates of return calculated will be grossly under-estimated and are only intended to confirm that they are above the hurdle rate commonly used for water supply projects. 6.12 In the "without project" scenario, the continued system deterioration would impose increased coping costs on domestic consumers. It is conservatively assumed that additional monthly coping costs of 2,000 VND would be imposed. These would increase by 2,000 VND per year stabilizing at a level of 10,000 VND per month after 5 years. Costs to non-domestic consumers and to the economy resulting from infrastructure bottlenecks are ignored. 6.13 Resource costs that merit consideration in a water supply project pertain to the cost of the raw water and environmental costs. In Hanoi, the groundwater aquifer is recharged from the Red River and is not mined. The reserves are estimated to be sufficient to meet demand upto 2010. There is no alternative use of the groundwater and therefore no opportunity cost is attributed. In Quang Ninh province, water is provided from a dedicated dam with no agricultural use and involving no opportunity cost. In Haiphong and Danang, surface water is used which could have alternative employment in agriculture. An opportunity cost of 50 VND/m3 is used based on data available from the National Tariff Study. 6.14 Environmental costs pertain to the cost of disposing the wastewater generated. However, in the proposed project, net additional water is not being produced. First, capacity expansion is limited. Second, the additional pped water produced by the WSCs would provide access to presently non-connected households. These households are presently using water from alternative sources which would be substituted by the piped water. Given that the project aims to provide 80% coverage at minimum consumption levels, the entire impact would be one of substitution, displacing non-piped sources. Therefore environmental costs are not imputed to the project. 6.15 Based on the above set of conservative assumptions and partial 1 The 1992 World Development Report, pp. 98-99, estimates that in Jakarta, Indonesia, households spend an amount equal to one percent of the city's gross domestic product, US$50 million, only on boiling water.
 44 quantification of benefits and costs, the estimates of the economic internal rates of return (EIRR) for the four project components and the overall project are as follows: Hanoi, 19%; Haiphong, 24%; Quang Ninh, 12%; Danang, 11%; and the overall project, 17%. All rates exceed the commonly used hurdle rate of 10t and confirm that the project as a whole and each component individually is economically justified. 6.16 Actual rates of return based on inclusion of all benefits are likely to be an order of magnitude higher than those computed and therefore quite robust against typical variations in costs and benefits. Benefits, in terms of avoided costs, have been estimated very conservatively. However, we can test project sensitivity to a further 10% decrease in benefits. Typical cost overruns are not expected to exceed lot of capital and O&M costs. Capital costs are designed to be controlled because of procurement through single supply and install contracts in each city. O&M costs have a lot of slack built in them because existing costs are not adjusted for efficiencies resulting from reduced electricity consumption because of replacement of ageing and obsolete equipment and from reduction in staff levels as the WSCs are commercialized. 6.17 Sensitivity analysis shows that the overall project rate of return falls from 17% to 12% for the worst case, where benefits decrease by 10% and both capital and O&M costs increase by 10%. For 10% percent variations from the base case, the rate of return is most sensitive to benefit reduction (falling to 14%), less sensitive to capital cost increases (falling to 15%) and least sensitive to an increase in O&M costs (falling to 16%). In no situation does the project EIRR fall below acceptable levels. Annex 12 presents the assumptions made in calculating the economic rates of return, the data used and the results including the sensitivity analysis. 6.18 An alternative approach to quantifying project benefits would be to use estimates of consumer willingness to pay per m3 of improved water. Studies in other countries have consistently found that average willingness-to-pay for better service exceeds the existing tariff charged. According to the survey carried out for the National Water Tariff Policy Study (para 5.3), this is also true in Vietnam, where the provision of water has been considered a social obligation and tariffs have been considerably subsidized. However, methodologically acceptable estimates of consumer willingness to pay for improved water are not available for the cities covered by the proposed project. D. Affordability 6.19 Because of the avoided coping costs detailed above, the total price of household water consumption is expected to fall after the project is implemented. However, affordability analyses available for most developing countries exclude coping costs and examine only the burden resulting from the price of piped water. Surveys conducted for the National Water Tariff Policy Study show that existing tariffs are affordable and that higher tariffs proposed by the Study could be charged in 1995 without exceeding 4 percent of household income for ordinary and "lifeline" domestic consumers. The 4 percent rule is commonly used as a measure of affordability for water supply. 6.20 Hanoi was the only city covered by the Study which is also included in the proposed project. Average monthly incomes for all households and those in the
 45 lowest quintile were estimated at 1,200,000 VND and 650,000 VND, respectively, while the corresponding expenditures for water were 19,500 VND and 11,300 VND. These expenditures translate into 1.6% and 1.5% of household income, well below the 4% threshold. The percentages were 2.6% and 2.8%, respectively in Thanh Hoa, the smallest and poorest urban center included in the survey. 6.21 Based on the results and affordability analysis, the Tariff Study proposed an average tariff for Hanoi of 3560 VND per cubic meter in 2000 (the average tariff in 1995 was 1420 VND) . By comparison, the financial projections for the proposed IDA project are based on a tariff of 2478 VND in the same year. Thus, the tariffs agreed to by the provincial governments are within the commonly accepted affordability threshold. Reduction of coping costs would further decrease the total costs presently being borne by households in the project cities. E. Project Risks 6.22 Since the physical components of the project deal primarily with rehabilitating existing facilities, there are no unusual risks. No irreversible environmental impacts are expected and the protection of water sources and options for disposal of treatment sludge (identified during project preparation) will be addressed through special studies during implementation. 6.23 The engineering preparation was guided by the need to reduce land acquisition and resettlement as much as possible. Thus, the project will require only limited land acquisition, relocation of population and demolition of houses because most of the treatment plants, intakes and wellfields are located away from residential areas. 6.24 A major risk to the project could stem from inadequate maintenance of the rehabilitated facilities. Therefore, as part of project preparation, the water companies have conducted an asset inventory which is being used to produce maintenance guidelines based on standard engineering codes of practice. These guidelines would be used to ensure adequate budgetary allocation for prevention and maintenance. 6.25 Another risk to project sustainability could arise from inadequate incentives to improve financial and managerial performance. Therefore, the project proposes a number of institutional development measures to be undertaken before and during project implementation. These include training field and office personnel, improving the billing, collection and customer management systems, introducing performance contracts between the provincial governments and the water supply companies, and public performance audits of all water supply companies by an independent agency. Collaboration with a reputable international water systems operator and with EDI has been initiated to assist with some of these tasks which are considered critical success factors for the project. 6.26 Shortage of counterpart funds and coordination of activities funded by different donors could slow project implementation. Financial plans indicating the level of funding required from the provincial governments have been discussed and agreed with the PCs and have been made part of the terms under which project components have been approved by the Office of Government. Coordination problems are mitigated by substantial assistance from the Resident Mission.

 105 ANNEX 7 VIETNAM WATER SUPPLY PROJECT Environmental impact Requirements 1. The Ministry of Science, Technology, and Environment (MOSTE) administers the Environmental Protection Law (EPL-1993) through its Department of Natural Resources and Environment. The Department is also responsible for recommendations on policy, rules, regulations, and guidelines, including environmental quality standards, and reviewing and approving environmental impact assessments (EIA) . The People's Committee (PC), assisted by provincial environmental department (DOSTE) is responsible for implementing the EPL, including monitoring and enforcement. 2. EIAs are required for development projects under the EPL. Large projects, including those with an investment cost of more than US$20 million, must submit an EIA to MOSTE for approval. For smaller projects, it is submitted to the DOSTE. 3. The project's land acquisition and resettlement would affect a limited number of people; most of the other negative impacts are temporary, which would be mitigated through good planning and construction practices. According to World Bank (WB) guidelines, the proposed project is classified as a category "B" project, which requires an environmental management plan (EMP) satisfactory to the Bank. Proiect Description 4. The project involves rehabilitation and expansion of water supply facilities in Hanoi, Haiphong, Quang Ninh, and Danang and will be implemented by the various cities' water supply companies (WSCs) from 1997-2001. Details are in Annex 2. EIA Studies 5. The EIAs were carried out as part of the feasibility studies and the reports are available in the project file. They concluded the project will positively affect the living standards and health conditions of the population. Rehabilitation of the existing facilities will decrease the level of non-revenue water while expansion of treatment plants and transmission and distribution lines will improve the quality of water provided and increase the amount of water supply, service levels and revenues. 6. The project's negative impacts would only be temporary, minor and reversible which can be mitigated through proper policy and project planning, public relations, and good construction and supervision practices. The engineering preparation of the project was guided by the requirement to reduce land acquisition and resettlement as much as possible. Therefore, the project will require only limited land acquisition, relocation of population and demolition of houses. 7. Serious negative impacts during site clearing, rehabilitation, and
 106 ANNEX 7 construction of the project facilities are not expected. Most of the WTPs, intakes, and other facilities are located far from residential areas. The mountainous area in Quang Ninh where raw water mains will be laid and the hill in Danang where the WTP will be constructed are degraded and serious impacts on ecology are not expected. Construction of the distribution networks will be carried out along the roads and sidewalks. While serious adverse impacts on residents are not anticipated, consultations with the affected population will be carried out prior to construction; in addition, at the design phase, efforts will be made to further reduce land requirements. The standard measures to mitigate the impacts during construction, including provision of adequate and safe water during the interruption the water services, will be required and included in the bidding and contract documents. 8. During operation, the WTPs would generate treatment sludge and improved water supply would contribute to increasing volumes of wastewater. The sludge would be disposed of in sludge retention lagoons in WTPs and when dried, disposed of in controlled landfills. Increases in wastewater volumes would have no significant impact on the current status; in addition, the sanitation project being prepared in the four cities would improve current conditions. 9. Serious impacts on water resources are not anticipated since the abstraction and pumping rates are relatively small compared to the annual average flow in the water resources. Monitoring of land subsidence and possible contamination of groundwater in Hanoi is important, and the program established and carried out by the city will be continued. For Quang Ninh, the safety of Cao Van dam will be improved and monitored. Trees and large shrubs in the reservoir were removed before filling, to improve the water quality. A program to protect the relevant watersheds, water quality at the intakes and in the water supply system against pollution will be developed and implemented (see Annex 2). Environmental Management Plans 10. In line with the EPL, the project's EIAs were cleared by MOSTE. Also, the World Bank requires that, based on the EIAs, the WSCs would prepare an environmental management plan (EMP) and a resettlement action plan (RAP) for each component. Accordingly, the WB received information on MOSTE's clearance and EMPs for each component before appraisal and found them satisfactory. 11. The EMPs summarize the mitigation measures proposed for the construction and operation of the components and are available in the project file. The measures are summarized below and those mitigating the adverse impacts due to land acquisition and resettlement are summarized in the next section. 12. During construction, the contractors will be required to carry out the works according to international standards, including consulting with residents; providing safe and adequate temporary paths for residents and businesses; providing adequate safety to the public and workers; implementing effective measures to reduce erosion, dust, and noise due to construction equipment; providing limited transport and construction along the main roads in urban areas during rush hours and in the residential areas at night; appropriately disposing of surplus soil and construction
 107 ANNEX 7 materials; and providing adequate water supply by other means when the system is interrupted. These requirements are included in the bidding documents and the contractors will be liable for all damages caused by non-compliance. 13. Prior to starting construction, the WSCs will inform the public and residents about the project through various means/media and EIA reports will be made available for public review. The public relation program will be carried out on a continuous basis. During construction, WSCs assisted by consultants, will cooperate with affected residents and take all measures needed to minimize the impacts to the residents and public. 14. The increase in the quantity of piped water produced would substitute for existing non-piped sources leading to minimal net increase in the quantity of wastewater generated. Pollution control is planned through a separate sanitation project now under preparation. To ensure adequate protection of water quality against pollution at the intakes and in the water supply systems, a monitoring program and various investigations will be conducted in each component; terms of references for the studies are available in the project file. Training will also be provided in the project to ensure effective operation and maintenance of the water supply facilities. 15. Specific programs for Hanoi, Quang Ninh and Danang systems will also be carried out under the project's technical assistance. This includes monitoring groundwater and land subsidence in Hanoi; enhancing the safety of Cao Van dam in Quang Ninh; and conducting a comprehensive study of Cau Do River in Danang. Technical assistance for Hanoi will be financed by the Finnish Government while for Quang Ninh and Danang, it will be provided by the Danish and the Australian Governments, respectively. Land Acquisition and Compensation 16. A total of about 36 ha will be acquired of which over one quarter are under the responsibility of government agencies. Most of the remaining hectares are rice fields; about 30 houses will be removed for the construction of an access road in Danang. The land acquisition process will be carried out in line with the national laws and appropriate compensation will be paid to the affected families. Land requirements for the project components are given in Annex 2 and summarized in Table A-7.1. 17. The government policy on land acquisition and compensation was reviewed during appraisal and found to be acceptable in principle. The Land Law (1993), and implementation directives issued by the provincial PCs stipulate land categories, compensation procedures, and price ceilings for loss of land and property (houses, other structures, trees, crops, etc). During the process, representatives of the affected families will be included on the compensation committees and will have the means to redress grievances. 18. The land acquisition process normally takes about 2-3 months and is summarized as follows:
 108 ANNEX 7 * The WSC, consulting with the local government (communes), will carry out a field survey identifying the type of land use, number of people affected, extent of the impacts, and the estimated amount of compensation; * The WSC will submit the survey with the request for land acquisition and a proposal for compensation to the Land Service Department (LSD); * After receiving the request, LSD will carry out a field inspection, confirming the type of land categories, number of the affected population and the level of compensation, and submit a recommendation to the provincial PC; * The PC will establish a compensation committee, consisting of representatives from the WSC, concerned agencies, local PC, and affected population to evaluate the adequacy of the compensation and consult/negotiate with the affected groups. The committee will submit the results to the PC for approval; * If agreement is reached, the WSC will compensate the affected people directly and the right to use the land will be transferred to the WSC, so construction can begin; * If the affected families are not satisfied with the decision, they can submit their proposals to the provincial PC for consideration within 15 days. The PC will respond to the proposal within 1 month; * Any land acquisition of more than 5 ha must be approved by the Prime Minister's Office. Implementation of the EMPs/RAPs 19. During appraisal, the compensation policy for each component was reviewed in the light of the World Bank policy on resettlement and the WSCs agreed to proceed as follows: * The proposed EMPs/RAPs presented in the project implementation plans (PIPs) will be timely and strictly implemented and results will be periodically reported to IDA; * During the design stage for the water mains and distribution networks, efforts will be made to minimize: (a) the impacts on houses, buildings and graves; (b) land requirements; and (c) excavation of large quantities of soil. The aim will also be to lay the pipes along the side of roads where impacts on households and businesses are less intrusive. Where the damages is more serious, pipes will be laid under the roads; * Bidding documents will include specific mitigation measures required during construction, and the contractors will be liable for damages caused by non- compliance; * EIAs will be made available for public review; consultation with the public and residents will be carried out through various means/media on a continuous basis; * During construction, the WSC, assisted by consultants, will supervise the work and inform residents and the public about all aspects of the project; * WSC will be responsible for preparing and implementing the RAP, consulting with the affected groups, and carrying out the land acquisition process according to national laws. Efforts will be made to ensure that the affected population are not worse off after the project, and that their incomes and living standards are recovered or improved. The process will be completed at
 109 ANNEX 7 least one month before construction begins; * The affected assets will be compensated at their replacement value and depreciation will not be considered during the calculation; * Representatives of the affected population will be included as members of the compensation committee to ensure their concerns are adequately addressed during the acquisition process and that the level of compensation is acceptable; * WSC will conduct a detailed survey on the affected population, including living standards, level of income, other social conditions, opinions about the project component, and the level of compensation and other assistance. Farmers loosing more than 25% of their total holdings will be identified, and a program to provide assistance will be developed so their economic conditions can be reconstituted. Results of the survey, including the level of compensation and payment schedule as proposed by WSC and, if possible, as agreed with the affected people, will be submitted to IDA for review; * Along with the above, WSC will proceed with the formal process and incorporate IDA comments; the compensation plan approved by the Government will then be submitted to IDA; * Land acquisition will be carried out in line with the project implementation schedule and will be completed at least one month before construction begins; Particular Actions * In Hanoi, a program to protect groundwater and the water supply system against pollution will be prepared and implemented, and the existing program to monitor groundwater and land subsidence will be continued; * In Haiphong, a program to protect water quality at Quan Vinh intake and the water supply system against pollution will be prepared and implemented; * In Quang Ninh, a program to strengthen safety at the Cao Van dam and to protect water quality at the intakes and in the water supply system against pollution will be prepared and implemented; * In Danang, details on the land acquisition of the access road from Yen Ne intake to the existing WTP at Cam Le will be prepared and submitted to IDA for review. Also, a program to study Cao Do River and protect water quality at the intakes and in the water supply system against pollution will be prepared and implemented. During appraisal, the WSCs confirmed the above agreements. Government Approval of the EIAs and Compliance 20. The EIA reports for the Hanoi, Haiphong, Quang Ninh and Danang components were submitted to MOSTE and the environmental clearances were obtained between August and October 1996. Each implementing agency (WSC) declared its willingness to comply with all conditions as required by MOSTE; compliance will be monitored by the DOSTEs. The MOSTE and DOSTE capacity, although still limited, is being gradually upgraded by the Government, helped by various bilateral grants.

This would include inter alia (i) providing guidance on timing and form of reporting implementation progress; (ii) arranging meetings with the government, provinces and water companies during mission's field visits; (iii) chairing mission's opening and wrap-up meetings; (iv) ensuring timely information to IDA; and (v) proposing satisfactory resolution of any unexpected issue occurring during implementation. The WBC would be assisted by the staff of Hanoi Resident Mission. 3. The following reports on implementation progress would be submitted to IDA: semiannually: (a) reports on implementation status, including monitoring of EMP and RAP; annually: (b) annual updated financial projections of water companies; (c) audited financial statements of water companies and Special Accounts for the credit including a separate opinion on Statement of Expenditures; and other: (d) evaluation report on project implementation and any report required on various subjects. Outline of semi-annual status report 4. The semi-annual status report will be prepared by each WSC. The report should comprise a descriptive part and appendices; the descriptive part should not exceed twenty pages and should cover the following items: (a) General description of the project. A concise summary of project objectives, description cities' components, financing, initial and latest estimated costs, initial and latest schedule, key data of credit and project agreements and of various amendments; (b) Project overview, physical accomplishment. Status of implementation progress for each component of the project, procurement, information on inspection of manufacturing, input of supervising consultant; monitoring of EMP and RAP, compliance during the reported period; (c) Procurement status. List of awarded contracts with dates of award, start and completion of contract, allowed time extensions, and variations, contract amounts in various currencies and status of disbursement for contracts, projected and actual disbursement S-curve for the total cost; (d) Institutional status. Progress of institutional improvements in water companies, performance of advisers and achievements in staff training; (e) Problems affecting implementation. Description of problems and proposed or taken actions. 5. Appendices will list personnel provided by the provinces and water companies, by the consultants and by contractors, key meetings, important visits on site, photographs, location plans of the project showing planned and achieved progress and monitoring indicators. 6. The report will include key monitoring indicators shown in Annex 11.
 113 ANNEX 8 Outline of the evaluation report on project implementation 7. The evaluation report will be prepared by each WSC. It should not exceed ten pages and the performance judgments and analyses should cover the following specific aspects: (a) Project objectives. A concise statement and evaluation of major objectives as presented in the SAR, including any changes made during implementation. The evaluation will assess the clarity of the objectives, their realism, and whether they are important for the country and sector. (b) Achievement of project objectives. An assessment of the project's success (substantial, partial, negligible) in achieving its major objectives - e.g. sector policy improvements, financial objectives, institutional development, physical objectives, other social objectives, environmental objectives, and public sector management and private sector development. (c) Implementation record and major factors affecting the project. An analysis of the factors that affect implementation. The factors are divided into those not generally subject to government or provinces control, those subject to government and provinces control, and those subject to water companies control. (d) IDA performance. An assessment of IDA's performance (highly satisfactory, satisfactory, deficient) in project identification, preparation assistance, appraisal, and supervision. (e) Water companies and provinces performance. An assessment of the performance of involved water companies and provinces (highly satisfactory, satisfactory, deficient) in preparing, implementing, and operating the project. (f) Assessment of outcome. A rating of outcome (highly satisfactory, satisfactory, unsatisfactory, or highly unsatisfactory) based primarily on how well the project achieved its objectives and how sustainable it is likely to be. (g) Future operation. A description and assessment of the plan for the project's future operation, including understanding the measures to maximize the project benefits, and the indicators for monitoring and evaluating future operations. (h) Key lessons learned. A discussion of the most significant positive and negative lessons learned from the project's implementation, showing how they are reflected in the arrangements for its future operations. This section also identifies those lessons most relevant to similar ongoing and future projects in this sector in Vietnam. 8. WSCs will submit the evaluation report to IDA after completing the project and in time stipulated in the Project Agreement.

 131 ANNEX 11 VIETNAM WATER SUPPLY PROJECT Project performance monitoring 1. The Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) system is designed to. provide managers with information on progress towards project objectives, impact on beneficiaries, and institutional, technical and financial aspects that could be useful in the commercial operation of the water supply companies. Three basic components would be proposed for the M&E system: a) Performance Agreements between the PCs and WSCs; b) Public Performance Audits (PPAs) of WSCs by an independent agency; and c) More traditional tracking of project milestones in terms of measuring progress achieved against specific targets in project implementation plans. Performance Agreements 2. Performance Agreements (PA) would be intended to provide incentives for the management of WSCs which are state enterprises to improve performance. The criteria, their base values and annual targets and weights, and the evaluation methodology would be agreed between the PCs and the management of WSCs at the beginning of each year. The PA would be closely linked to the Corporate Plan of the WSC. Bonus payments would be linked to performance measured against the PA. Performance Agreements introduced for state enterprises including WSCs in Thailand would be used as the model to be adapted to the specific conditions in Vietnam. Public Performance Audits 3. An independent agency would collect information on performance indicators of WSCs and make comparative information available for public disclosure. The information would include indicators most relevant to consumers such as water quality, pressure, reliability, etc. A simple grading system based on color coding (e.g., gold for good, green for acceptable, black for unacceptable) would make the information easily comprehensible to consumers. Public disclosure of comparative information would generate pressure to improve performance and competition amongst the water supply companies. Project Milestones 4. Traditional milestones, in addition to the above, would be used to evaluate project progress by the supervision missions. A detailed list of indicators is provided in Table A 11.1 while key performance indicators relevant during project implementation, agreed upon during negotiations, are highlighted in Table A 11.3. The key performance indicators were identified using the Performance/Risk Summary shown in Table A 11.2.

 139 ANNEX 12 VIETNAM WATER SUPPLY PROJECT Rate of return Data 1. Data for the "without project" scenario is taken from the WSCs' income statements in Annex 9. The base year is taken to be 1995, the last full year for which complete accounts are available. Data on water produced, percentage of water billed and average tariff are used to compute gross revenues. Operating expenses are adjusted by deleting the item for non-collected bills which is not an expense and the item for connection charges which would be financed out of the capital budget. For purposes of the rate of return computation, the "without project" scenario assumes the 1995 values to remain constant in real terms except for operating expenses which are assumed to increase in real terms by 0.5% per year due to system deterioration. The base values are shown in Table A 12.1. 2. For the "with project" scenario, Table A 12.2 shows the project investment costs (from Annex 3), excluding price contingencies, and the phasing of annual investment used in the analysis. Operating costs are also taken from Annex 9 and projected using 1995 unit costs for the various cost categories, except staff costs, and multiplying them by the amount of water produced in each year. Thus no efficiency gains or economy of scale factors are built in. Staff costs are projected to increase at 4% per year in real terms reflecting rising real income levels in Vietnam. Both investment costs and operating costs are in constant 1995 values. 3. No additional water is assumed to be available till 2000. However, non-revenue water is projected to begin decreasing earlier as technical assistance focused on improved billing and collection will be completed prior to the project becoming effective. This is reasonable since administrative losses greatly exceed physical losses in WSCs in Vietnam. Tariffs are also assumed to increase from 1997 as this has been agreed with the PPCs. The variables are assumed to reach steady state in 2004. Assumptions 4. For the economic analysis, all costs are expressed in 1995 prices, making no adjustments for shadow exchange rate or shadow labor costs in line with the assumption made in Power sector projects in Vietnam. Electricity costs are not adjusted as the WSCs are being charged 600 VND per kWh which is the long run marginal cost of supply at the high voltage level. Staff and electricity costs comprise the bulk of operating costs. There is some evidence that prices of chemicals are subsidized to the WSCs. However, these are less than 10% of total operating costs and are not adjusted. Rather, any likely impact is evaluated through sensitivity analysis on total operating costs. The sensitivity results indicate that it is not worthwhile to make adjustments for the distortion in the price of chemicals. Household size is taken to be 4.5 in each city. Results 5. Tables A 12.3, A 12.4 and A 12.5 show the data used, the computations and the sensitivity analysis for the FIRR. Tables A 12.6, A 12.7 and A 12.8 are the corresponding tables for the EIRR.

doc.abstracts: The aims of the Water Supply Project in Hanoi, Haiphong, Halong City/Cam Pha in Quang Ninh, and Danang are to: (i) improve the quality of water supply services in the four cities through renovation of existing facilities in order to satisfy demand up to 2000 of about 2.5 million people in the cities; (ii) ensure sustainability of the physical investments by developing the institutional capabilities of water supply agencies, facilitating their commercialization, and upgrading their staff skills through training; and (iii) assist in preparation of a future investment program to satisfy water demand after 2000. The project will include the following components: 1) renewal and upgrading of water supply facilities in the urban districts of Hanoi, Haiphong and Danang, and Halong/Cam Pha in Quang Ninh province; 2) institutional measures to ensure sustainability of the physical investments; 3) support activities consisting of various studies, advisory services, supervision of construction and training; and 4) resettling and rehabilitating of population affected by the project.
